import pyspark.sql.functions as F
import pyspark.sql.types as T
from pyspark.sql.window import Window

def preprocessing_anomaly_detection(df):

    # Selecting just relevant columns for anomaly detection
    new_df = df.select('ActiveWBS', 'SubscriptionName', 'MeterCategory', 'Date', 'CostInBillingCurrency')

    # Filtering out data older than 180 days to get only the latest historical data
    threshold = F.date_sub(F.current_date(), 365)
    filtered_df = new_df.filter(F.col('Date') >= threshold)

    # Grouping the data by each filtering level and getting the sum of all costs related to the filtering columns
    grouped_df = filtered_df.groupBy('ActiveWBS', 
                                     'SubscriptionName', 
                                     'MeterCategory', 
                                     'Date').agg(F.round(
                                                  F.sum(
                                                   F.col('CostInBillingCurrency')), 1).alias('TotalCost'))

    return grouped_df

def anomaly_detection_classifier(df,
                                 filter_column_1, 
                                 filter_column_2,
                                 # cost_column,
                                 filter_tag,
                                 window_size=30):

    
    # # Selecting the filter-categories (Subscription and Meter Category), the time-stamp and the cost data
    # costs_by_dates = df.select(filter_column_1, filter_column_2, 'Date', cost_column)

    # Setting a partition window to divide the dataset in the filter options and order it by the Date
    windowSpec = Window.partitionBy(filter_column_1, filter_column_2).orderBy('Date').rowsBetween(-window_size, 0)


    # Define column-names
    ma_col_name = f'MovingAverage_{filter_tag}'
    std_col_name = f'MovingStdDev_{filter_tag}'

    # Set a moving average that is set by the n previous days
    costs_by_dates = df.withColumn(ma_col_name, F.round(F.avg(F.col('TotalCost')).over(windowSpec), 1))

    # Set a moving standard deviation of the same period
    costs_by_dates = costs_by_dates.withColumn(std_col_name, F.round(F.stddev(F.col('TotalCost')).over(windowSpec), 1))

    # Setting a scaling mechanism on the threshold in order to reduce the threshold when the costs are very high
    am_curve = lambda x: 13.6 * x ** -0.22

    costs_by_dates = costs_by_dates.withColumn(f'Scaler_{filter_tag}', F.when(F.col(std_col_name) > 0.1, am_curve(F.col(std_col_name))).otherwise(F.lit(0.1)))
    costs_by_dates = costs_by_dates.withColumn(f'Scaler_{filter_tag}', F.when(F.col(f'Scaler_{filter_tag}') > 3, F.lit(3)).otherwise(F.col(f'Scaler_{filter_tag}')))

    costs_by_dates = costs_by_dates.withColumn(f'Threshold_{filter_tag}', F.col(ma_col_name) + (F.col(std_col_name) * F.col(f'Scaler_{filter_tag}')))

     # If the cost is more than the stddev threshold (+ some noise cancellation), then set the datapoint to be 1, otherwise 0
    costs_by_dates = costs_by_dates.withColumn(f'Above_Threshold_{filter_tag}', F.when(F.col('TotalCost') > (F.col(f'Threshold_{filter_tag}') + 1), F.lit(1))\
                                                                                 .otherwise(F.lit(0)))

    return costs_by_dates

source_path = "abfss://usage@s037costmgmt.dfs.core.windows.net/exports/monthly/aggregate/parquet/Extended_ACMMonthlyAmortizedCost_overview_OneYear.parquet"

print(f"Reading data from: {source_path}")
df = spark.read.format('parquet').load(source_path)

preproc_data = preprocessing_anomaly_detection(df)

print("Running the Anomaly Detection Classifier for Subscription-partitioned data")
costs_by_dates =  anomaly_detection_classifier(df=preproc_data,
                                               filter_column_1='SubscriptionName',
                                               filter_column_2='MeterCategory',
                                               # cost_column='TotalCost',
                                               filter_tag='Subscription',
                                               window_size=30)
